thread.title: The 10 most expensive (and cheapest) cities to retire in
thread.title_full: The 10 most expensive (and cheapest) cities to retire in - seattlepi.com

author: seattlepi.com
title: The 10 most expensive (and cheapest) cities to retire in
text:
Don’t plan to retire in a big city. If you do, don’t plan to ever retire.
Finance website Smart Asset calculated the average savings necessary to retire in various U.S. cities. By looking at average annual expenditures for seniors ($42,557) and adjusting for cost of living and tax rates, here’s how expensive retirement can get*.
RELATED: The 10 best Houston suburbs where you should retire
New York City retirees would need to save $2.25 million to “maintain the average standard of living” over 30 years. No city is more costly for retirement than the Big Apple. Other cities like Stamford, Conn. and San Francisco cost require more than $1 million in savings to retire.
Of the 10 cheapest cities to retire, four are in Texas. Pensioners in the border town of McAllen only need $369,857 to subsist for 30 years. Amarillo, San Marcos and Sherman also offered cheap retirement options in the Lone Star State.
See the 10 cheapest and most expensive cities for retirement in the gallery above.
*The site also assumes “seniors would receive $17,189 in Social Security income (the national average).”
